greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Numbers whose number of divisors is a power of 2.
comment: Primes and A030513(d(x)=4) are subsets; d(16k+4) and d(16k+12) have the form 3Q, so x=16k+4 or 16k-4 numbers are missing.
A number m is a term if and only if all its divisors are infinitary, or A000005(m) = A037445(m). - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Feb 23 2017

All exponents in the prime number factorization of a(n) have the form 2^k-1, k >= 1. So it is an S-exponential sequence (see Shevelev link) with S={2^k-1}. Using Theorem 1, we obtain that a(n) ~ C*n, where C = Product((1-1/p)*(1 + Sum_{i>=1} 1/p^(2^i-1))). - _Vladimir Shevelev_ Feb 27 2017
This constant is C = 0.687827... . - _Peter J. C. Moses_, Feb 27 2017
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(n) << n. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Feb 25 2017
example: 383, 384, 385, 386 have 1, 16, 8, 4 divisors, respectively, so they are consecutive terms of this sequence.
mathematica: bi[ x_ ] := 1-Sign[ N[ Log[ 2, x ], 5 ]-Floor[ N[ Log[ 2, x ], 5 ] ] ]; ld[ x_ ] := Length[ Divisors[ x ] ]; Flatten[ Position[ Table[ bi[ ld[ x ] ], {x, 1, m} ], 1 ] ]
xref: Complement of A162643; subsequence of A002035. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 08 2009
results.author: _Labos Elemer_
